bibl.title: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, July 5, 1924

div1.p: Fricks reports on the progress of malaria investigations conducted in the southern United States.

div1.head: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, July 5, 1924
div1.opener:
Malaria
Report
FB
July 5, 1924.
Monthly Progress Report,
June, 1923.
The Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress
report of malaria investigations conducted during the month
of June, 1923, under the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: Personnel - Special
Expert M. A. Barber, Assoc. San.Eng. W.H.W.Komp and Tech.
Asst. Theo. B. Hayne.

Activities at the Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Study
of effect of hydrogen-ion concentration and of different foods
on the development of mosquito larvae; (2) Observations and ex-
periments with larvicides, mosquito repellents and top-feeding
minnows; (3) Surveys of malaria rates and anopheline intensi-
ty: (a) Anopheles bred out from larvae or pupae, practically
all from rice fields, 743, of which approximately 38% were A.
quadrimaculatus, 63% A. crucians and one specimen A. walkeri;
(b) Anopheles caught in imago stage, nearly all from the vic-
inity of rice fields, 3752, of which approximately 30% were
A. quadrimaculatus, 70% A. crucians and three specimens A.
walkeri ( a group of imagoes identified in a cypress swamp were
practically all A. quadrimaculatus); (c) Blood specimens exam-
ined for malaria parasites, 21 specimens submitted by physi-
cians showed four positive, all P. vivax; 31 specimens exam-
ined from a logging camp, none positive.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A.A.Surg. Wm. A.Krauss and
Microscopists Ethel Barrier and Retha Kitchens.

618 blood smears were examined for malaria parasites, of which
226 were collected from school children in Chatham County, Ga.,
four of these were positive P. vivax; 69 smears were sent in
Monthly Progress Report
-2-
July 5, 1924.
for examination by Surgeon L.L.Williams, Richmond, Va.,
eleven of these were positive, P. felc., and five posi-
tive P. vivax; 325 smears were sent in for diagnosis from
Memphis and its vicinity, of which seven were positive, P.
felc. and 36 positive, P. vivax. Fifty home visits were
made in the study of malaria carriers under treatment.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Georgia: Personnel - Techni-
cal Asst. Bruce. Mayne.

Activities consisted of (1) observations on incidence and
distribution of Anopheles; imagoes collected 393, A. cruc-
ians 281, A. quadrimaculatus 112, distributed as follows:

A decided proportional increase of A. quadrimaculatus during
the month; (2) 87 specimens A. crucians and 12 A.quadrimacu-
latus dissected, none found infected; (3) 121 blood specimens
submitted for diagnosis showed only one positive, P. vivax;
(4) observed that the drying of natural breeding places has
resulted in abundant Anopheles production in water troughs,
concrete vats and roadside puddles; (5) No special geometri-
cal pattern observed in collections of Anopheles eggs.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surg.
Kenneth F. Maxcy.

Dr. Maxcy visited eight southern state health departments dur-
ing the month for the purpose of (1) ascertaining what informa-
tion has been collected by them regarding the distribution of
malaria in the different states; (2) studying the methods em-
ployed in the different states for collecting malaria statis-
tics; (3) interesting the various state health departments in
securing more accurate registration of malaria deaths and im-
proving malaria morbidity reporting; (4) and increasing inter-
est in the diagnosis of malaria by blood examinations.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemio-
logist T.H.D. Griffitts and Asst. San. Eng. E.H. Gage.

Dr. Griffitts (Alabama), activities consisted of (1) Inspec-
tions of Golden Bridge Pond June 9, 24 and 25th, water low,
much floatage stranded, pond oiled every ten days with oil
under 120 pound pressure, very little mosquito production,
Monthly Progress Report
-3-
July 5, 1924.
no house infestation; (2) Inspection of Gentt's Quarry Pond
June 8th, much floatage, extensive growth of algae, light
anopheline breeding; (3) Inspection of Mitchell Reservoir
June 12th, 13 and 14th, water turbid, drift and floatage
less than last season, gambusia apparently less numerous,
no full grown larvae found; (4) Inspected fishing pond at
Selma, June 17th, Anopheles producing freely, light house
infestation, A. quadrimaculatus.

Mr. Gage (South Carolina) continued observations of preva-
lence of Anopheles larvae in Horse Creek Valley, Aiken
County: (1) nearly thirteen times as many larvae found per
dip in areas other than impounded waters than in the ponds
themselves; a marked increase in relative production observed
during June, which was due more to a decrease in breeding in
the impounded waters, although the production in the small
bodies of water was actually nearly doubled; (2) the number
of adults found per resting place examined was about half
the number found in May, but the proportion of from away
from to one adjacent to impounded water projects held good;
the majority of adults collected were A. crucians with a
noticeable increase in A. quadrimaculatus; (3) A house-to-
house survey was begun in an attempt to locate malaria foci
in Horse Creek Valley.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Assoc. San.
Eng. A. H. Fuchs.

Mr. Fuchs continued the study of major drainage in relation
to malaria by making an inspection of Drainage District No. 6
in Crittenden County, Arkansas, to determine the amount of
Anopheles production in drainage ditches under delta condi-
tions; Observations are being recorded with a view to estab-
lishing the relation which exists between Anopheles produc-
tion in these ditches and such conditions as size of ditch,
soil, velocity of flow, obstruction, vegetation, floatage,
top minnows, and so forth.

Cooperative Fish Studies: Mr. Samuel F. Hildebrand of the
Bureau of Fisheries resumed his cooperative fish control in-
vestigations at Augusta, Georgia: (1) A ceries of experi-
ments was begun for the purpose of gaining further knowledge
of the true value of Gambusia as eradicators of mosquito
larvae under a variety of conditions; (2) Mr. LePrince and
Mr. Hildebrand inspected, June 18th and 19th, twenty-five
Gambusia hatcheries constructed in the Cherokee Basin (Dr.
Griffitts reported these hatcheries as producing Anopheles
Monthly Progress Report
-4-
July 5, 1924.
freely last month). Mr. Hildebrand and Mr. LePrince found
that only a few of the twenty-five ponds created were serv-
ing their purpose well, due primarily to faulty location
and construction.

Rural Malaria Control Investigations: Asst. San. Eng. J. C.
Carter, A.A. Surg. C. P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng. L. M. Fisher,
Asst. San. Eng. J.G. Foster, Asst. San. Eng. H. N. Old, Asst.
San. Eng. P. R. Shaws and Surg. L.L. Williams, Jr.

Mr. Old (Georgia), activities consisted of continuation of
observations of mosquito breeding at 56 stations scattered
over the county, seven of the 56 stations found producing,
21 dry because of scant rainfall; 622 larvae and pupae col-
lected, of which 600 were collected at two stations; 115
resting places searched for adult mosquitoes, 506 female and
seven male A. crucians collected, 100 female and four male
A. quadrimaculatus collected; the most important resting
places reported were:
Investigations of bamboo ane as drain tile undertaken.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana) continued malaria control investigations
in Yangipahos and St. Mary's Parishes; (1) Investigation of
malaria prevalence in St. Mary's arish by school census,
11,571 persons reached, malaria history rate of 8.3%, 5.1% for
screened houses and 10.4% for unscreened houses; survey of
Patterson Swamp completed, recommended the digging of a large
outlet ditch through swamp; mosquito control campaign inaugur-
ated at Patterson.

Dr. Coogla and Mr. Foster (Mississippi), rural malaria control
investigations continued in Leflore County (1) Observations of
Anopheles incidence; four inspections of selected mosquito rest-
ing places made, enormous increase of Anopheles noted between
Monthly Progress Report
-5-
July 5, 1924.
June 9th and 15th, more than twelve times as many Anopheles
mosquitoes noted as during the month of May, one A. puncti-
pennis female and no crucians encountered; (2) Anopheles
larvae and pupae became suddenly abundant the second week in
June.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina), rural malaria control investiga-
tions continued, profuse mosquito breeding observed in seepage
area containing salamanders; observations of effectiveness of
star head minnows in controlling mosquito production under obs-
ervation in large pond near Columbia, Anopheles larvae found
along with these fish throughout the pond; county health in-
spector of Newberry County instructed in differentiating mos-
quitoes, in dipping and in collecting adults.

Surgeon L.L. Williams (Virginia), investigation of rural malaria
control continued in Accomac, Hansemond, Northampton, James City,
Henrico, Isle of Wight, Greensville, and Halifax Counties; pre-
vailing mosquitoes A. punctipennis and A. crucians until late in
June, except in Hansemond County which has had A. quadrimacula-
tus since May; from the middle of May there has been a slow,
steady increase in the number of adult Anopheles observed.

Conferences and Inspections: Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A. Le
Prince inspected the impounded water projects on Horse Creek,
Aiken County, S.C.; surveyed Bridge Water Pond, McDowell County,
H.C.; inspected Chatham County, Ga. studies; inspected Gambusia
Hatcheries in Cherokee Basin, Alabama; inspected Muscle Sloals
Lake.

Medical Officer in Charge conferred with the State Health Offi-
cer of Georgia at Atlanta, Ga.; conferred with Asst. San. Eng.
E. H. Gage at Augusta, Georgia; conferred with Asst. San. Eng.
H. N. Old and Tech. Asst. Bruce Mayne at Savannah, Ga.; conferred
with state health officials and Mr. Carter in Montgomery, Ala.;
conferred with Dr. Maxcy, Memphis, Tennessee.

Expenditures: During the month of June approximately $5,788.10
was expended from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field
investigations of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
